{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3721750,"name":"Mike","username":"msorola","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/4bbf92/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-08-23T15:13:19.993Z","cooked":"

Hi, our team purchased an Omio MPC-125 about a year ago and we used it this past season to make all of our robot parts. It was a game changer for us. The one issue we are running into is the workflow of the whole process, especially with aluminum extrusion parts. Right now these are the steps we follow:

  1. Student or Mentor creates CAD model of part in Fusion
  2. Students cut raw stock and then square up on the mill. They choose the best side and label each face A, B, C, or D going clockwise around the tube as well as putting the part name on the piece.
  3. At the same time, another student creates CAM program to cut the features on the part, labeling each NC program with the corresponding label (ABCD).
  4. When we’re ready to CNC it, we pull the file from Fusion onto a flash drive and take it to the CNC to be cut.

For the most part this works ok, but we do have some issues that slow us down. We use names for parts, so sometimes a student will save something as a “crossbeam” instead of a “crossbrace” and another person will think they are two different things. After the parts are squared up we put them in a pile to be processed, but it never fails that someone will put a part that hasn’t been squared in that pile, or stuff will get moved around because our space is limited, and we end up having to verify the part is square. We’ve tried using both a paper and a shared document to keep track of the process of each piece but the paper one eventually disappears and sometimes parts get done and whoever did them doesn’t bother to update the shared document so we’re not sure if the part is actually complete or not.

TLDR:
We’re brand new to manufacturing our own parts and I know we can do it more efficiently and with less waste. If anyone could share what works for them or any tips they might have it would be greatly appreciated!

Use part numbers (including version numbers) rather than names and a Google sheet for tracking. For ready to route stock, you could put a sharpie symbol on it indicating that it’s been squared/otherwise fully prepared.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-08-23T15:37:52.025Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":110,"readers_count":109,"score":147.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":505598,"topic_slug":"manufacturing-process-tips","display_username":"Jim Sokoloff","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":8}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66298,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"97 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/manufacturing-process-tips/505598/2","custom_user_title":"97 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":7},{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":8,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3721761,"name":"Chun-che Lo","username":"Attention","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/attention/{size}/65287_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-23T15:38:09.448Z","cooked":"
  1. Part numbers consistent across project management, CAD, and labeled parts. I once had a student name something “full coverage insurance” instead of assigning it a part number and everyone was very confused.
  2. Shelves for labeled stock and a separate one for finished parts. Takes space, but visually informs students about machining needs and makes it easy to find parts.
  3. Inspection before and after between each stage. For example, person making stock checks it’s correct after squaring, then the person machining the part checks that the stock is squared.

Bonus points if the project management can assign or ping people to make sure that the student understand it’s their responsibility to check that each step of the process.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-08-23T15:38:09.448Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":110,"readers_count":109,"score":92.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":505598,"topic_slug":"manufacturing-process-tips","display_username":"Chun-che Lo","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28264,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Currently Job Hunting"},"post_url":"/t/manufacturing-process-tips/505598/3","custom_user_title":"Currently Job Hunting","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3721782,"name":"Ryan Fredrickson","username":"RyanisnotBatmab","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ryanisnotbatmab/{size}/231954_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-23T16:19:47.809Z","cooked":"

So glad to hear you guys getting into the world of manufacturing.

So from what I am hearing from your post you are struggling with part management and communicating the status of parts. I was my teams lead machinist for 2 years and now am a machinist by trade so I’ll try and offer some guidance.

When it comes to part management, how you name your parts is very important. When I name a part I try and convey its purpose in 4-6 words. For example if I have a tube that works as a support for my elevator I could name it “Elevator to drivebase diagonal support” I know it’s wordy but it gives a very identifiable name. I also strongly recommend part numbers, they make organizing much easier. There are plenty good examples out there of part numbering systems online.

Now when it comes to communicating part status my biggest peice of advice that I can testify to in FRC and in my professional experience, is having clear paperwork. I know it’s not flashy and not the most fun but it makes life much easier.

What I mean by paperwork is having a part drawing of the part that is to be made, on the drawing have a checkbox for preprocessed, made, and post-processed.

Once the drawing is made a student will take it and do the preprocess, cutting stock to length, squaring stock, labeling sides and creating a NC program. Then indicate that pre process is done on the paperwork using a checkbox or just writing it. Now once the stock goes to the ready to be machined pile, I recommend using some painters tape to tape the paperwork/drawing to the stock until it needs to go on the machine. This allows people to one, see the status of this part, and two see what the part is named and how many need to be made.

Then load your stock up and get to making chips!

Once the parts off the machine then you can indicate that the part has been machined on the drawing. Next you move to post post processing, this is doing things like tapping holes, reaming holes, deburing, even things like powder coating or painting if you wanted to add those to the process. I like to reattach the paperwork to the parts until they get put on the robot.

I know that’s a lot of information but this is system that has worked well for me.

Any more questions feel free to ask!

Some good suggestions here already regarding manufacturing/management processes; Especially adopting the use of part #'s.

msorola:

Students cut raw stock and then square up on the mill.

Depending on your setup, it may also be possible to skip the squaring up your saw-cut stock on the mill. Instead, have one of your first operations on the router be facing/squaring off either end of your stock (this can also potentially help hold accurate final lengths of your extrusion/part).
